snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes reports of Apple apps crashing after updates, the same malware found in the Apple and Android apps stores and ...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes reports of Apple apps crashing after updates, the same malware found in the Apple and Android apps stores and a video explaining the subatomic particle that physicists said this week that they had discovered.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Crashing Apps and App Store Malware

snippet: After Google showed off its computerized glasses last week, Olympus announced its MEG 4.0 display glasses and Apple has been awarded a patent for a display projected into a person’s eye.
abstract: After Google showed off its computerized glasses last week, Olympus announced its MEG 4.0 display glasses and Apple has been awarded a patent for a display projected into a person’s eye.

headline.main: Olympus and Apple Join Google With Wearable Computing

snippet: The Google Nexus Q home entertainment device is a little bit bewildering.
abstract: The Google Nexus Q home entertainment device is a little bit bewildering.

headline.main: The Google Nexus Q Is Baffling

snippet: The shortage of retail stores and authorized resellers leaves room for unlicensed resellers. Bad experiences at unauthorized shops run the risk of eroding confidence in Apple’s products.

headline.main: Apple's Retail Expansion Falls Short in China
headline.print_headline: Apple's Retail Expansion Falls Short in China

snippet: The gold standard in pocket-size amplified speakers has been the Soundmatters foxL. But a line of Braven speakers has challenged its superiority, and a listening test reveals a surprise winner.
abstract: The gold standard in pocket-size amplified speakers has been the Soundmatters foxL. But a line of Braven speakers has challenged its superiority, and a listening test reveals a surprise winner.

headline.main: A Pocket-Size Speaker With Some Punch

snippet: On Saturday nights, regulars still line up at Roll-N-Roaster, which opened in Sheepshead Bay more than 40 years ago.
abstract: Roll-N-Roaster fast food restaurant in Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn is still popular among regulars more than 40 years after opening; customers say not much has changed over the decades, reminding many of a forgotten Brooklyn past (Series: Summer Nights).

headline.main: Dining on Roast Beef, Lemonade and Nostalgia
headline.print_headline: Dining on Roast Beef, Lemonade and Nostalgia

snippet: With thousands of photography apps available, photos can be much more creative.
abstract: Kit Eaton App Smart column highlights smartphone apps for creative photography.

headline.main: With a Little Help, Photos That Impress Your Friends
headline.print_headline: With a Little Help, Photos That Impress Your Friends

snippet: Google’s Nexus 7, a sleek, full-blown tablet with the latest version of Android 4.1, is playing Follow the Leader with Apple’s iPad, David Pogue says.
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column highlights Google's new Nexus 7, a sleek, full-blown tablet with the latest version of Android 4.1; notes it aims to challenge Amazon's Kindle Fire and Apple's iPad, and costs only $200.

headline.main: A Tablet to Rival the Leader
headline.print_headline: A Tablet To Rival The Leader

snippet: Music festivals have become big business, and promoters are looking to New York for future successes.
abstract: Summer music festivals in New York City, once thought of by promoters as impractical because of the crowded cultural calendar, high costs and competition for large public spaces, are becoming more common.

headline.main: Music Festivals Make a Move Into New York
headline.print_headline: Music Festivals Make a Move Into New York

snippet: Need a temporary close-up showing part of the computer's screen so you can see something better? Some versions of Windows and Mac OS X let you do just that.     Windows XP, Windows Vista and Windows 7 include a utility called Magnifier that offers...
abstract: Personal Tech Q&A Tip of the Week shares information about a utility called Magnifier that offers several ways to zoom in to specific areas of a computer's screen. (S)
